"More than two-thirds of India's population may have COVID-19 antibodies, according to a new serological survey released Tuesday, providing yet more evidence the virus may have spread far more widely than official figures suggest."
"Health workers and scientists have long warned that the real toll of cases and deaths are likely much higher than reported, pointing to the discrepancy between official figures and the sero-surveys."
"Regardless of source and estimate, actual deaths during the Covid pandemic are likely to have been an order of magnitude greater than the official count," the study noted. "True deaths are likely to be in the several millions not hundreds of thousands, making this arguably India's worst human tragedy since partition and independence.""
https://www.ctvnews.ca/health/coronavirus/more-than-two-thirds-of-india-may-have-covid-19-antibodies-blood-survey-shows-1.5518970 That high natural immunity would also explain why the rate is staying low despite easing restrictions. I considered the following figures: As of 20 July, India had some 31.2m COVID cases as per the WHO (so 8.8m less than 40m). For the past 4 weeks, the weekly number of cases stabilized at a lower level, ranging between 268k-361k new cases per week, compared to 2.7m in a week at the peak of the last COVID wave. Looking into India, Pakistan and Bangladesh, previous "low tides" of infection seemed to last between 5-15 weeks. Vaccination is still slow, with 24% of the population receiving the 1st dose according to Reuters. My most-likely scenario (60%) assumes that the current "low tide" lasts about 10 weeks at current levels. So in the next 6 weeks we may have about 1.7m cases. If it was as dramatic as the last one, we would see about 7.6m new cases in the first 5 weeks, meaning we would surpass the 40m mark in slightly less than 11 full weeks - so late-Sep or early-Oct. However, I would assume that the next wave may be less drastic than the recent one, given the lessons learned and gradual increase in # of vaccinated people. So my most-likely scenario (55%) is that we reach 40m after 1 Oct.   However, a new COVID wave could start sooner. If it starts today (21 Jul) and is as dramatic as the last one (e.g. new variant and low restrictions), we could see over 10m cases in the first 6 weeks like in the last wave. This means we would reach 40m cases around late-Aug or early-Sep. It seems unlikely given the average length of low tides, lessons learned from the last wave and increased vaccination, although I am not sure about the willingness of India to reimplement tough restrictions. Because of that, I assigned a 40% likelihood for 1-30 Sep and a 5% likelihood for 1-31 Aug.

WHO can report 40 million cases in one of two ways:
1) a fundamental amendment of the case count due to distrust in the government's reporting, for which there are numerous sources to say that the cases are being unreported (e.g. https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/fullarticle/2776292)
2) the official case count reaches 40 million WHO does not seem to have amended any case counts, per a google search. Further, the case counts are reported by India to WHO, per https://covid19.who.int/info/ So, let's assume that (1) will happen with very low probability. (2) will happen either at a steady or rate or accelerated due to another major outbreak or COVID variant. Due to the amount of spread and case unreporting, the probability of a new variant is reasonably high. There are three weeks until July 31st, so the probability of getting 10 million more cases in that time due to another outbreak is fairly low. For the following months, the probability increases due to continuous chances from now till then for new outbreaks or variants.
At this point, even an aggressive resurgence of a new variant would be difficult to break 40M by Oct. 1. Anything less than a 10% weekly increase in cases resolves to bin 5.

I no longer believe cases will reach 40M by 1st October.

Currently (12th July 2021) WHO reports that India has had 30,752,950 confirmed cases of Covid-19. Estimates
To try and estimate a likely number that will happen by the end of July I've gone for attempting to see what the midpoint number is between the last big peak of out breaks (April 19th - May 17th = ~11,740,000 confirmed cases) and recent 'trough' numbers  in a later period (June 5th - July 7th = ~1,910,000) (numbers calculated from data: https://covid19.who.int/region/searo/country/in). The midpoint between these is ~6,800,000 for approximately a 4 week period. Using this number added to the current total, 40 million will be reached in August unless another peak starts after this prediction is made for July. New Variants
The delta strain present in India is ~60% more infectious than the alpha strain (https://www.nature.com/articles/d41586-021-01696-3). Yale Medicine epidemiologist Dr. F. Perry Wilson commented “In the same environment [no vaccination, no masks], Delta would spread from one person to maybe 3.5 or 4 other people.” https://www.yalemedicine.org/news/5-things-to-know-delta-variant-covid (updated July 9th). Vaccines
However the number of people vaccinated in India has increased and is currently at 357,553,612 doses (if everyone had just one dose this would be 26% of the population of India) https://covid19.who.int/region/searo/country/in. Further the current vaccines being administered have shown to be effective against the Delta strain at single dose (~30% effective) and double dose (60-88%) https://www.nature.com/articles/d41586-021-01696-3 Lockdowns
Different states have different actions. On the 1st of July the trend in lockdown practices seemed to be easing curfews and requirements. https://www.firstpost.com/india/covid-19-lockdown-list-of-states-that-have-extended-or-eased-restrictions-starting-today-9770241.html Given the highly infectious Delta strain, the possibility of new variants being spread, the large number of people yet to be vaccinated, and the easing of lockdowns, and using estimates based on the midpoint between peak infections and current infections,  I think it is highly likely that 40 million will be reached in August 31st. But the rate may go down as vaccination is received by more people, so have also included some probability of it happening in September or post October. I think that it won't be reached by 31st of July as on the 12th of July WHO records 30.75 million cases. Another 9.25 million cases would need to be confirmed over the next 3 weeks. While this is less than the spring outbreak (April 19th - May 17th = ~11,740,000 confirmed cases), the current graphs do not indicate increased numbers trend and the rising to another 'wave' at this stage for July.

It's looking more likely to me that the decline will slow. Looking at 2020, it took 40 days for cases to fall from a peak of 93k in mid September to <50k - and that was as seasonal pressures were waning. So, let's suppose that it takes 2 months for cases to fall from their current 123k/day to 50k/day (which might not happen at all, as cases could rise again or decline more slowly or faster). This would add in the ballpark of 5.2M cases to the current total of 28.9M, for a total of 34.1M by Aug. 7. At 50k/day after that, another 1.2M would be added by the end of August, followed by 1.5M by the end of Sept, for a total of 36.8M. That's *if* sufficient restrictions are kept in place to keep cases declining, even as seasonality makes spread more likely.

Confirmed cases are falling a bit more slowly than they rose but are thankfully still falling fast. In perhaps a bit over 2 weeks, the country will hopefully report ~100k cases/day. At that point, the total number of recorded cases would be just under 30M. If cases plateaued at 100k/day, then India would see 40M cases in September. If lockdowns were lifted too early, cases would easily rise again. If lockdowns continue and cases keep falling, cases could plateau around 50k/day or less. But it should be kept in mind that the seasonal peak is likely to be around mid-September, so if restrictions are lifted too early, we can expect cases to come roaring back. In other words, substantial restrictions will likely need to remain in place through September to prevent a resurgence. Then the question will be whether regions around the country will be able to continue such restrictions.

My approximations follow . . . Best case: Second third of August. Worst case: Last third of July. Ultra worst case: June 20s or first third of July. Blend of worst and best: First week of August. Blend of ultra worst and best: July 20s. Blend of best, worst, and ultra worst:  July 20s. My best guess: The end of the first week of August. But I laugh at how ridiculously precise these are for such low confidence. The reason I don't put too much weight in the first bin is that the basic idea of large spikes like India is that once the curve is not flattened and goes in fact vertical, it's reasonable to believe susceptible people are now recovered (SEIRS model). The virus is everywhere now, with most cases outside large cities, especially, going undetected. The federal government is not acting, in contrast with last year. State governments are then being left hanging out to dry politically and will be more likely to succumb to pressures to reopen. I wouldn't be surprised if they reopen in patchwork patterns that are not perhaps very correlated with case counts. In about 10 days, India will be at ~28M cases total and ~200k cases/day, with ~66 days left before July 31. They'd have to stay <182k/day average through July 31 to avoid 40M cases by then, and they probably will. (I don't think reaching 40M before July 1 is likely at this point, given lockdowns.) They might get down to ~100k cases/day and park there for a while. If states keep up restrictions, it'll take another ~10 days for cases to fall to ~100k/day, and another ~1.9M cases will be added, so that the total for India will likely be just under 30M around June 6. If the country does bring cases down to 100k/day, then I think 40M would be unlikely by July 31, because that would require >180k cases/day average for the remainder of the period. To get to 40M by August 31 would require 116.3k cases/day, which is certainly more possible. Also, note that respiratory virus infections tend to be more common in the monsoon season, which travels across the country from late May/early June through late September/early October. I don't think it's a coincidence that last year's peak was Sept. 17. I do think it's very likely that 40M cases will be reached by Oct. 1; that would require an average of ~86k cases/day from June 6 through Sept. 30 if cases were brought down to 100k cases/day by June 6. Last year, India was at 50k cases/day and 1.7M cumulative cases on July 31. It took until March 23, 2021 to reach 10M more cases, and there was a far larger susceptible population then. I think that if India forces cases to fall to 50k/day over the coming weeks, then reaching 40M cases will be unlikely before Oct 1. Need to watch and wait to see how far down the country brings cases before lifting restrictions. Summary:
* With restrictions, India will bring cases down to ~200k/day by May ~27 and total to ~28M; bring cases down to ~100k/day by June ~6 and total to just under 30M by July 31.
* If cases are brought to 100k/day by June 6, then >180k/day needed to reach 40M by July 31, >116k/day needed to reach 40M by Aug. 31, >86k/day needed by Sept. 30.
* If cases are brought to 50k/day by June ~17, then India will be at ~31M, and it will be less likely that 40M cases will be reached by Oct. 1.
* In the absence of restrictions, expect cases to peak during monsoon season, probably around mid-September like last year. In other words, restrictions will be needed more during the upcoming months to slow spread.

I don't know what to expect right now. The previous forecast for India/SE Asia was clear: the authorities would do too little, too late. Now there are many restrictions, but will they lift them too soon? Moreover, restrictions are imposed in many places, but spread in areas outside larger cities is increasing, and such spread will largely go unmeasured and not enter into this forecast. In part because of ongoing spread outside larger cities, as soon as restrictions are lifted, cases will come roaring back. Will the authorities in different places lift restrictions in 2 weeks, 1 month, 2 months, longer? The federal government imposed extensive restrictions for long durations in 2020, but is there sufficient political will for comparable restrictions now? And restrictions would need to be imposed for longer time periods now because cases are at a much higher level now. I just don't have a feel for what will happen yet. The only thing that is becoming increasingly clear is that 40M will likely not be reached by July 31. The average cases/day would need to be ~199k/day for the remaining 77 days before July 31 for India to reach 40M cases. India will likely see ~200k/day in ~11 +/-1 day, probably adding just under 3.5M to the total number of cases. Then cases/day would need to stay under an average of about 180k/day until July 31 to stay under 40M. One smaller problem is that the Indian gov't has relied on spectacularly amateurish modeling efforts to guide its actions, and it's not clear whether that will change.
https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/government-backed-model-to-predict-pandemic-rise-and-ebb-lacks-foresight-scientists/article34479503.ece
The larger problem is that the government will face giant pressure from all sides to keep things closed and to open things up, and it will likely do whatever it thinks at the moment will be the best course for improving the re-election chances of BJP candidates. So this is really a forecast about Indian politics, and I'm not sure yet which way the wind will blow.

It's hard to say though whether that's only due to less prevalent testing (Our World in Data shows India's testing relative to population is also a lot lower than the US). So I think it's very possible that India's cases could still go up quite a bit from here. India is currently at 20% of tests returned as positive per Our World in Data. With the above considerations in mind here are the average numbers to hit the different dates (based on 23 million cases currently): 51 days to July 1, need to average less than 333k cases per day to get past.
81 days until July 31, need to averageless than 210k cases per day to get past.
112 days until August 31, need to average less than 152k cases per day to get past.
142 days until September 30, need to average less than 120k cases per day to get past. Currently India is around 387k cases per day for the rolling average and maybe starting to peak. Based on the above considerations I think there's a good chance cases stay around the same level or go higher, and to get past the first bucket India needs a pretty quick drop. I don't think a quick drop is impossible but it is unlikely, most peaks seem to plateau for a little while before coming down (US over the winter for example and Brazil currently). Several factors seem pertinent for a forecast that is likely several weeks into the future. - Since the recent weeks have shown massive increase, there is a bias (recency?) to make a naive extrapolation. To combat that, let me list factors that will apply brakes to this increase.
a) Behavior: This is the best lever we have in the short-term to slow down the pandemic- in this case- fear may impose the discipline, probably accompanied by lockdowns.
b) Vaccination : Not likely to be effective in the next month or so- however, we may be underestimating the how much things can change after that - aid, production capacity increases etc (a) will help in slowing down case increases through May (Google Mobile data can help to monitor this).  Will power, unfortunately has a short shelf life. We had seen the greatest increase in cases previously in  ( July-Sep) 2020 -which is the time of monsoon and weddings in India and there is a good chance we may see another peak (not as high as the current one).  One hopes that the vaccination supply shortages would be alleviated by then, but the vaccine administration will likely become the bottleneck then. As of Apr-30: cases ~ 20 m which means 10 m cases needed to be added in May & June for the tally to reach 40 m. As of May 10, the rolling monthly~ 9.6m, but the important thing is the first difference ( difference between successive days) is falling. Which means the rolling monthly might peak at 10 m in May, and then trend down for a few weeks -> unlikely to hit 40 m before July 1.

Expecting temporary restrictions to have a dramatic but short-lived affect, combined with scale of the issues and population size prolonging the downward curve. Forecast to reach 40M around the first 2 weeks of July, but the timeline is prone to significant shifts dependant on changing conditions, so I think it will be difficult to gauge accurately for a few weeks yet.

We seem primed for week-over-week cases to see first declines in the next 7-10 days. Unless such declines are very insignificant, Bin1 will quickly cease to be an option. Outside view is that the decay of surges in most countries is somewhere between symmetrical and lognormal in shape. India may prove to break that pattern, but they would have to do so in striking fashion to hit Bins1 or Bin2.

I do not trust the government will be able to have an effective strategy to get cases down - in fact, I suspect the slow down in numbers is an artifact, a sign they can't even tally their dead. Given the PM has been responsible for super spreader events, and given the inequality, supplies sent to India will probably only be used for the healthcare of elites, while the disease keeps spreading among the lower classes.

How big is India's epidemic going to get? Cases are still growing, but testing is leveling off and nearing saturation. Overall test positivity rate is 21% for the country, 32% in New Delhi (down from a peak of 36%), and varies across states; it's as high as 62% in Rajasthan, and as low as 5% in Mizoram. Because testing is nearing saturation, it's hard to know what's really going on. There does appear to be an inflection point in the 7day average of cases/day somewhere around April 16 to 21, but it's hard to know whether that's real. Actual cases could be continuing to climb exponentially out of control. Currently, total at 21.49M, with 390k cases/day and still slightly climbing. Obviously, most cases are being missed, but confirmed cases still give us a useful measure of the size of the problem. In the press, I see speculation that cases in New Delhi and Maharashtra will likely peak in May, other places in June. I'm not sure I see why they should peak in May.
Anyway, 18.51M to go to get to 40M. 55 days left before July 1; would require 337k cases/day to reach 40M by July 1. On April 6, there were 93k cases/day (7day average), so things can go up and down very quickly. I suspect we have weeks more to go, though, before the epidemic in India truly turns around. If one estimates that India is underestimating deaths by ~10x, then they have reached about as many deaths as a proportion of the population as the US has. But they don't have nearly enough vaccinations or control measures to slow this down yet.
I think India will easily reach 30M cases by July 1. If the epidemic peaks in the next couple weeks or so, then 40M cases may not be reached by July 1. But if it peaks around June 1 or after, then I think 40M is assured, unless they run out of testing supplies. I think the peak of the epidemic for the country as a whole may not be reached until sometime in June. On the other hand, areas outside major cities may have limited testing capabilities, so the true peak may not show up in the testing data. Still, I think it's very likely that India will reach 40M cases before July 1.
